text: After Moses the Lord’s servant died, the Lord said to Joshua son of Nun, Moses’ assistant:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Moses my servant is dead. Get ready! Cross the Jordan River. Lead these people into the land that I am ready to hand over to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am handing over to you every place you set foot, as I promised Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your territory will extend from the desert in the south to Lebanon in the north. It will extend all the way to the great River Euphrates in the east (including all Syria) and all the way to the Mediterranean Sea in the west.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one will be able to resist you all the days of your life. As I was with Moses, so I will be with you. I will not abandon you or leave you alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong and brave! You must lead these people in the conquest of this land that I solemnly promised their ancestors I would hand over to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make sure you are very strong and brave! Carefully obey all the law my servant Moses charged you to keep. Do not swerve from it to the right or to the left, so that you may be successful in all you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: This law scroll must not leave your lips. You must memorize it day and night so you can carefully obey all that is written in it. Then you will prosper and be successful.
speaker: Narrator

text: I repeat, be strong and brave! Don’t be afraid and don’t panic, for I, the Lord your God, am with you in all you do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua instructed the leaders of the people:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go through the camp and command the people, ‘Prepare your supplies, for within three days you will cross the Jordan River and begin the conquest of the land the Lord your God is ready to hand over to you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua told the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember what Moses the Lord’s servant commanded you. The Lord your God is giving you a place to settle and is handing this land over to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your wives, children, and cattle may stay in the land that Moses assigned to you east of the Jordan River. But all of you warriors must cross over armed for battle ahead of your brothers. You must help them
speaker: Narrator

text: until the Lord gives your brothers a place like yours to settle and they conquer the land the Lord your God is ready to hand over to them. Then you may go back to your allotted land and occupy the land Moses the Lord’s servant assigned you east of the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They told Joshua, “We will do everything you say. We will go wherever you send us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as we obeyed Moses, so we will obey you. But may the Lord your God be with you as he was with Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any man who rebels against what you say and does not obey all your commands will be executed. But be strong and brave!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua son of Nun sent two spies out from Shittim secretly and instructed them: “Find out what you can about the land, especially Jericho.” They stopped at the house of a prostitute named Rahab and spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Jericho received this report: “Note well! Israelite men have come here tonight to spy on the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Jericho sent this order to Rahab: “Turn over the men who came to you—the ones who came to your house—for they have come to spy on the whole land!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the woman hid the two men and replied, “Yes, these men were clients of mine, but I didn’t know where they came from.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was time to shut the city gate for the night, the men left. I don’t know where they were heading. Chase after them quickly, for you have time to catch them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now she had taken them up to the roof and had hidden them in the stalks of flax she had spread out on the roof.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the king’s men tried to find them on the road to the Jordan River near the fords. The city gate was shut as soon as they set out in pursuit of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now before the spies went to sleep, Rahab went up to the roof.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to the men, “I know the Lord is handing this land over to you. We are absolutely terrified of you, and all who live in the land are cringing before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we heard how the Lord dried up the water of the Red Sea before you when you left Egypt and how you annihilated the two Amorite kings, Sihon and Og, on the other side of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we heard the news we lost our courage and no one could even breathe for fear of you. For the Lord your God is God in heaven above and on earth below!
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, promise me this with an oath sworn in the Lord’s name. Because I have shown allegiance to you, show allegiance to my family. Give me a solemn pledge
speaker: Narrator

text: that you will spare the lives of my father, mother, brothers, sisters, and all who belong to them, and will rescue us from death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men said to her, “If you die, may we die too! If you do not report what we’ve been up to, then we will show unswerving allegiance to you when the Lord hands the land over to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rahab let them down by a rope through the window. (Her house was built as part of the city wall; she lived in the wall.)
speaker: Narrator

text: She told them, “Head to the hill country, so the ones chasing you don’t find you. Hide from them there for three days, long enough for those chasing you to return. Then you can be on your way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men said to her, “We are not bound by this oath you made us swear unless the following conditions are met:
speaker: Narrator

text: When we invade the land, tie this red rope in the window through which you let us down, and gather together in your house your father, mother, brothers, and all who live in your father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who leaves your house will be responsible for his own death—we are innocent in that case! But if anyone with you in the house is harmed, we will be responsible.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you should report what we’ve been up to, we are not bound by this oath you made us swear.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “I agree to these conditions.” She sent them on their way and then tied the red rope in the window.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to the hill country and stayed there for three days, long enough for those chasing them to return. Their pursuers looked all along the way but did not find them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the two men returned—they came down from the hills, crossed the river, came to Joshua son of Nun, and reported to him all they had discovered.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told Joshua, “Surely the Lord is handing over all the land to us! All who live in the land are cringing before us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bright and early the next morning Joshua and the Israelites left Shittim and came to the Jordan. They camped there before crossing the river.
speaker: Narrator

text: After three days the leaders went through the camp
speaker: Narrator

text: and commanded the people: “When you see the ark of the covenant of the Lord your God being carried by the Levitical priests, you must leave here and walk behind it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But stay about 3,000 feet behind it. Keep your distance so you can see which way you should go, for you have not traveled this way before.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua told the people, “Ritually consecrate yourselves, for tomorrow the Lord will perform miraculous deeds among you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua told the priests, “Pick up the ark of the covenant and pass on ahead of the people.” So they picked up the ark of the covenant and went ahead of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Joshua, “This very day I will begin to honor you before all Israel, so they will know that I am with you just as I was with Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instruct the priests carrying the ark of the covenant, ‘When you reach the bank of the Jordan River, wade into the water.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua told the Israelites, “Come here and listen to the words of the Lord your God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua continued, “This is how you will know the living God is among you and that he will truly drive out before you the Canaanites, Hittites, Hivites, Perizzites, Girgashites, Amorites, and Jebusites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look! The ark of the covenant of the Lord of the whole earth is ready to enter the Jordan ahead of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now select for yourselves twelve men from the tribes of Israel, one per tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the feet of the priests carrying the ark of the Lord, the Lord of the whole earth, touch the water of the Jordan, the water coming downstream toward you will stop flowing and pile up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the people left their tents to cross the Jordan, the priests carrying the ark of the covenant went ahead of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the ones carrying the ark reached the Jordan, and the feet of the priests carrying the ark touched the surface of the water—(the Jordan is at flood stage all during harvest time)—
speaker: Narrator

text: the water coming downstream toward them stopped flowing. It piled up far upstream at Adam (the city near Zarethan); there was no water at all flowing to the sea of the rift valley (the Salt Sea). The people crossed the river opposite Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests carrying the ark of the covenant of the Lord stood firmly on dry ground in the middle of the Jordan. All Israel crossed over on dry ground until the entire nation was on the other side.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the entire nation was on the other side, the Lord told Joshua,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Select for yourselves twelve men from the people, one per tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instruct them, ‘Pick up twelve stones from the middle of the Jordan, from the very place where the priests stand firmly, and carry them over with you and put them in the place where you camp tonight.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua summoned the twelve men he had appointed from the Israelites, one per tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua told them, “Go in front of the ark of the Lord your God to the middle of the Jordan. Each of you is to put a stone on his shoulder, according to the number of the Israelite tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: The stones will be a reminder to you. When your children ask someday, ‘Why are these stones important to you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: tell them how the water of the Jordan stopped flowing before the ark of the covenant of the Lord. When it crossed the Jordan, the water of the Jordan stopped flowing. These stones will be a lasting memorial for the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did just as Joshua commanded. They picked up twelve stones, according to the number of the Israelite tribes, from the middle of the Jordan as the Lord had instructed Joshua. They carried them over with them to the camp and put them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua also set up twelve stones in the middle of the Jordan in the very place where the priests carrying the ark of the covenant stood. They remain there to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the priests carrying the ark of the covenant were standing in the middle of the Jordan until everything the Lord had commanded Joshua to tell the people was accomplished, in accordance with all that Moses had commanded Joshua. The people went across quickly,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when all the people had finished crossing, the ark of the Lord and the priests crossed as the people looked on.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh crossed over armed for battle ahead of the Israelites, just as Moses had instructed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: About 40,000 battle-ready troops marched past the Lord to fight on the rift valley plains of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day the Lord brought honor to Joshua before all Israel. They respected him all his life, just as they had respected Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Joshua,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Instruct the priests carrying the ark of the covenantal laws to come up from the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua instructed the priests, “Come up from the Jordan!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests carrying the ark of the covenant of the Lord came up from the middle of the Jordan, and as soon as they set foot on dry land, the water of the Jordan flowed again and returned to flood stage.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people went up from the Jordan on the tenth day of the first month and camped in Gilgal on the eastern border of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joshua set up in Gilgal the twelve stones they had taken from the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told the Israelites, “When your children someday ask their fathers, ‘What do these stones represent?’
speaker: Narrator

text: explain to your children, ‘Israel crossed the Jordan River on dry ground.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God dried up the water of the Jordan before you while you crossed over. It was just like when the Lord your God dried up the Red Sea before us while we crossed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has done this so all the nations of the earth might recognize the Lord’s power and so you might always obey the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the Amorite kings on the west side of the Jordan and all the Canaanite kings along the seacoast heard how the Lord had dried up the water of the Jordan before the Israelites while they crossed, they lost their courage and could not even breathe for fear of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Lord told Joshua, “Make flint knives and circumcise the Israelites once again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua made flint knives and circumcised the Israelites at the Hill of the Foreskins.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is why Joshua had to circumcise them: All the men old enough to fight when they left Egypt died on the journey through the wilderness after they left Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now all the men who left were circumcised, but all the sons born on the journey through the wilderness after they left Egypt were uncircumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, for forty years the Israelites traveled through the wilderness until all the men old enough to fight when they left Egypt, the ones who had disobeyed the Lord, died off. For the Lord had sworn a solemn oath to them that he would not let them see the land he had sworn by oath to their ancestors to give them, a land rich in milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: He replaced them with their sons, whom Joshua circumcised. They were uncircumcised; their fathers had not circumcised them along the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the men had been circumcised, they stayed there in the camp until they had healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Joshua, “Today I have taken away the disgrace of Egypt from you.” So that place is called Gilgal even to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites camped in Gilgal and celebrated the Passover in the evening of the fourteenth day of the month in the rift valley plains of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: They ate some of the produce of the land the day after the Passover, including unleavened bread and roasted grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: The manna stopped appearing the day they ate some of the produce of the land; the Israelites never ate manna again. They ate from the produce of the land of Canaan that year.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joshua was near Jericho, he looked up and saw a man standing in front of him holding a drawn sword. Joshua approached him and asked him, “Are you on our side or allied with our enemies?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, “Truly I am the commander of the Lord’s army. Now I have arrived!” Joshua bowed down with his face to the ground and asked, “What does my master want to say to his servant?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The commander of the Lord’s army answered Joshua, “Remove your sandals from your feet, because the place where you stand is holy.” Joshua did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jericho was shut tightly because of the Israelites. No one was allowed to leave or enter.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Joshua, “See, I am about to defeat Jericho for you, along with its king and its warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have all the warriors march around the city one time; do this for six days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have seven priests carry seven rams’ horns in front of the ark. On the seventh day march around the city seven times, while the priests blow the horns.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you hear the signal from the ram’s horn, have the whole army give a loud battle cry. Then the city wall will collapse, and the warriors should charge straight ahead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua son of Nun summoned the priests and instructed them, “Pick up the ark of the covenant, and seven priests must carry seven rams’ horns in front of the ark of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he told the army, “Move ahead and march around the city, with armed troops going ahead of the ark of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joshua gave the army its orders, the seven priests carrying the seven rams’ horns before the Lord moved ahead and blew the horns as the ark of the covenant of the Lord followed behind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Armed troops marched ahead of the priests blowing the horns, while the rear guard followed along behind the ark blowing rams’ horns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joshua had instructed the army, “Do not give a battle cry or raise your voices; say nothing until the day I tell you, ‘Give the battle cry.’ Then give the battle cry!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua made sure they marched the ark of the Lord around the city one time. Then they went back to the camp and spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bright and early the next morning Joshua had the priests pick up the ark of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven priests carrying the seven rams’ horns before the ark of the Lord marched along blowing their horns. Armed troops marched ahead of them, while the rear guard followed along behind the ark of the Lord blowing rams’ horns.
speaker: Narrator

text: They marched around the city one time on the second day, then returned to the camp. They did this six days in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day they were up at the crack of dawn and marched around the city as before—only this time they marched around it seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventh time around, the priests blew the rams’ horns, and Joshua told the army, “Give the battle cry, for the Lord is handing the city over to you!
speaker: Narrator

text: The city and all that is in it must be set apart for the Lord; only Rahab the prostitute and all who are with her in her house will live, because she hid the spies we sent.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be careful when you are setting apart the riches for God. If you take any of it, then you will make the Israelite camp subject to annihilation and cause a disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the silver and gold, as well as bronze and iron items, belong to the Lord. They must go into the Lord’s treasury.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The rams’ horns sounded, and when the army heard the signal, they gave a loud battle cry. The wall collapsed, and the warriors charged straight ahead into the city and captured it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They annihilated with the sword everything that breathed in the city, including men and women, young and old, as well as cattle, sheep, and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua told the two men who had spied on the land, “Enter the prostitute’s house and bring out the woman and all who belong to her as you promised her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the young spies went and brought out Rahab, her father, mother, brothers, and all who belonged to her. They brought out her whole family and took them to a place outside the Israelite camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they burned the city and all that was in it, except for the silver, gold, and bronze and iron items they put in the treasury of the Lord’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet Joshua spared Rahab the prostitute, her father’s family, and all who belonged to her. She lives in Israel to this very day because she hid the messengers Joshua sent to spy on Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Joshua made this solemn declaration: “The man who attempts to rebuild this city of Jericho will stand condemned before the Lord. He will lose his firstborn son when he lays its foundations and his youngest son when he erects its gates!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was with Joshua and he became famous throughout the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites disobeyed the command about the city’s riches. Achan son of Carmi, son of Zabdi, son of Zerah, from the tribe of Judah, stole some of the riches. The Lord was furious with the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua sent men from Jericho to Ai (which is located near Beth Aven, east of Bethel) and instructed them, “Go up and spy on the land.” So the men went up and spied on Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: They returned and reported to Joshua, “Don’t send the whole army. About two or three thousand men are adequate to defeat Ai. Don’t tire out the whole army, for Ai is small.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So about 3,000 men went up, but they fled from the men of Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Ai killed about thirty-six of them and chased them from in front of the city gate all the way to the fissures and defeated them on the steep slope. The people’s courage melted away like water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua tore his clothes; he and the leaders of Israel lay face down on the ground before the ark of the Lord until evening and threw dirt on their heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua prayed, “O, Sovereign Lord! Why did you bring these people across the Jordan to hand us over to the Amorites so they could destroy us? If only we had been satisfied to live on the other side of the Jordan!
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, what can I say now that Israel has retreated before its enemies?
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Canaanites and all who live in the land hear about this, they will turn against us and destroy the very memory of us from the earth. What will you do to protect your great reputation?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord responded to Joshua, “Get up! Why are you lying there face down?
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel has sinned; they have violated my covenantal commandment! They have taken some of the riches; they have stolen them and deceitfully put them among their own possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites are unable to stand before their enemies; they retreat because they have become subject to annihilation. I will no longer be with you, unless you destroy what has contaminated you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get up! Ritually consecrate the people and tell them this: ‘Ritually consecrate yourselves for tomorrow, because this is what the Lord God of Israel has said, “You are contaminated, O Israel! You will not be able to stand before your enemies until you remove what is contaminating you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning you must approach in tribal order. The tribe the Lord selects must approach by clans. The clan the Lord selects must approach by families. The family the Lord selects must approach man by man.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one caught with the riches must be burned up along with all who belong to him, because he violated the Lord’s covenant and did such a disgraceful thing in Israel.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bright and early the next morning Joshua made Israel approach in tribal order, and the tribe of Judah was selected.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then made the clans of Judah approach, and the clan of the Zerahites was selected. He made the clan of the Zerahites approach, and Zabdi was selected.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then made Zabdi’s family approach man by man and Achan son of Carmi, son of Zabdi, son of Zerah, from the tribe of Judah, was selected.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua said to Achan, “My son, honor the Lord God of Israel and give him praise! Tell me what you did; don’t hide anything from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Achan told Joshua, “It is true. I have sinned against the Lord God of Israel in this way:
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw among the goods we seized a nice robe from Babylon, 200 silver pieces, and a bar of gold weighing 50 shekels. I wanted them, so I took them. They are hidden in the ground right in the middle of my tent, with the silver underneath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua sent messengers who ran to the tent. The things were hidden right in his tent, with the silver underneath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took it all from the middle of the tent, brought it to Joshua and all the Israelites, and placed it before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua and all Israel took Achan, son of Zerah, along with the silver, the robe, the bar of gold, his sons, daughters, oxen, donkeys, sheep, tent, and all that belonged to him and brought them up to the Valley of Disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said, “Why have you brought disaster on us? The Lord will bring disaster on you today!” All Israel stoned him to death. (They also stoned and burned the others.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they erected over him a large pile of stones (it remains to this very day) and the Lord’s anger subsided. So that place is called the Valley of Disaster to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Joshua, “Don’t be afraid and don’t panic! Take the whole army with you and march against Ai! See, I am handing over to you the king of Ai, along with his people, city, and land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do to Ai and its king what you did to Jericho and its king, except you may plunder its goods and cattle. Set an ambush behind the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua and the whole army marched against Ai. Joshua selected 30,000 brave warriors and sent them out at night.
speaker: Narrator

text: He ordered them, “Look, set an ambush behind the city. Don’t go very far from the city; all of you be ready!
speaker: Narrator

text: I and all the troops who are with me will approach the city. When they come out to fight us like before, we will retreat from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will attack us until we have lured them from the city, for they will say, ‘They are retreating from us like before.’ We will retreat from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you rise up from your hiding place and seize the city. The Lord your God will hand it over to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you capture the city, set it on fire in keeping with the Lord’s message. See, I have given you orders.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua sent them away and they went to their hiding place west of Ai, between Bethel and Ai. Joshua spent that night with the army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bright and early the next morning Joshua gathered the army, and he and the leaders of Israel marched at the head of it to Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the troops that were with him marched up and drew near the city. They camped north of Ai on the other side of the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took 5,000 men and set an ambush west of the city between Bethel and Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The army was in position—the main army north of the city and the rear guard west of the city. That night Joshua went into the middle of the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Ai and all his people saw Israel, they rushed to get up early. Then the king and the men of the city went out to meet Israel in battle, at the meeting place near the rift valley. But he did not realize an ambush was waiting for him behind the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua and all Israel pretended to be defeated by them, and they retreated along the way to the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the reinforcements in Ai were ordered to chase them; they chased Joshua and were lured away from the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: No men were left in Ai or Bethel; they all went out after Israel. They left the city wide open and chased Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Joshua, “Hold out toward Ai the curved sword in your hand, for I am handing the city over to you.” So Joshua held out toward Ai the curved sword in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he held out his hand, the men waiting in ambush rose up quickly from their place and attacked. They entered the city, captured it, and immediately set it on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Ai turned around, they saw the smoke from the city ascending into the sky and were so shocked they were unable to flee in any direction. In the meantime the men who were retreating to the wilderness turned against their pursuers.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joshua and all Israel saw that the men in ambush had captured the city and that the city was going up in smoke, they turned around and struck down the men of Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the same time the men who had taken the city came out to fight, and the men of Ai were trapped in the middle. The Israelites struck them down, leaving no survivors or refugees.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they captured the king of Ai alive and brought him to Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel had finished killing all the men of Ai who had chased them toward the wilderness (they all fell by the sword), all Israel returned to Ai and put the sword to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So 12,000 men and women died that day, including all the men of Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua kept holding out his curved sword until Israel had annihilated all who lived in Ai.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Israel did plunder the cattle and the goods of the city, in keeping with the Lord’s orders to Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua burned Ai and made it a permanently uninhabited mound (it remains that way to this very day).
speaker: Narrator

text: He hung the king of Ai on a tree, leaving him exposed until evening. At sunset Joshua ordered that his corpse be taken down from the tree. They threw it down at the entrance of the city gate and erected over it a large pile of stones (it remains to this very day).
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua built an altar for the Lord God of Israel on Mount Ebal,
speaker: Narrator

text: just as Moses the Lord’s servant had commanded the Israelites. As described in the law scroll of Moses, it was made with uncut stones untouched by an iron tool. On it they offered burnt sacrifices to the Lord and sacrificed tokens of peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: There, in the presence of the Israelites, Joshua inscribed on the stones a duplicate of the law written by Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people, rulers, leaders, and judges were standing on either side of the ark, in front of the Levitical priests who carried the ark of the covenant of the Lord. Both resident foreigners and native Israelites were there. Half the people stood in front of Mount Gerizim and the other half in front of Mount Ebal, as Moses the Lord’s servant had previously instructed them to do for the formal blessing ceremony.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua read aloud all the words of the law, including the blessings and the curses, just as they are written in the law scroll.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua read aloud every commandment Moses had given before the whole assembly of Israel, including the women, children, and resident foreigners who lived among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the news reached all the kings on the west side of the Jordan—in the hill country, the foothills, and all along the Mediterranean coast as far as Lebanon (including the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites)—
speaker: Narrator

text: they formed an alliance to fight against Joshua and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the residents of Gibeon heard what Joshua did to Jericho and Ai,
speaker: Narrator

text: they did something clever. They collected some provisions and put worn-out sacks on their donkeys, along with worn-out wineskins that were ripped and patched.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had worn-out, patched sandals on their feet and dressed in worn-out clothes. All their bread was dry and hard.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came to Joshua at the camp in Gilgal and said to him and the men of Israel, “We have come from a distant land. Make a treaty with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel said to the Hivites, “Perhaps you live near us. So how can we make a treaty with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they said to Joshua, “We are willing to be your subjects.” So Joshua said to them, “Who are you and where do you come from?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him, “Your subjects have come from a very distant land because of the reputation of the Lord your God, for we have heard the news about all he did in Egypt
speaker: Narrator

text: and all he did to the two Amorite kings on the other side of the Jordan—King Sihon of Heshbon and King Og of Bashan in Ashtaroth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our leaders and all who live in our land told us, ‘Take provisions for your journey and go meet them. Tell them, “We are willing to be your subjects. Make a treaty with us.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: This bread of ours was warm when we packed it in our homes the day we started out to meet you, but now it is dry and hard.
speaker: Narrator

text: These wineskins we filled were brand new, but look how they have ripped. Our clothes and sandals have worn out because it has been a very long journey.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men examined some of their provisions, but they failed to ask the Lord’s advice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua made a peace treaty with them and agreed to let them live. The leaders of the community sealed it with an oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days after they made the treaty with them, the Israelites found out they were from the local area and lived nearby.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites set out and on the third day arrived at their cities—Gibeon, Kephirah, Beeroth, and Kiriath Jearim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did not attack them because the leaders of the community had sworn an oath to them in the name of the Lord God of Israel. The whole community criticized the leaders,
speaker: Narrator

text: but all the leaders told the whole community, “We swore an oath to them in the name of the Lord God of Israel! So now we can’t hurt them.
speaker: Narrator

text: We must let them live so we can escape the curse attached to the oath we swore to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders then added, “Let them live.” So they became woodcutters and water carriers for the whole community, as the leaders had decided.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua summoned the Gibeonites and said to them, “Why did you trick us by saying, ‘We live far away from you,’ when you really live nearby?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you are condemned to perpetual servitude as woodcutters and water carriers for the house of my God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Joshua, “It was carefully reported to your subjects how the Lord your God commanded Moses his servant to assign you the whole land and to destroy all who live in the land from before you. Because of you we were terrified we would lose our lives, so we did this thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now we are in your power. Do to us what you think is good and appropriate.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua did as they said; he kept the Israelites from killing them
speaker: Narrator

text: and that day made them woodcutters and water carriers for the community and for the altar of the Lord at the divinely chosen site. (They continue in that capacity to this very day.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Adoni-Zedek, king of Jerusalem, heard how Joshua captured Ai and annihilated it and its king as he did Jericho and its king. He also heard how the people of Gibeon made peace with Israel and lived among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Jerusalem was terrified because Gibeon was a large city, like one of the royal cities. It was larger than Ai and all its men were warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Adoni-Zedek of Jerusalem sent this message to King Hoham of Hebron, King Piram of Jarmuth, King Japhia of Lachish, and King Debir of Eglon:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Come to my aid so we can attack Gibeon, for it has made peace with Joshua and the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the five Amorite kings (the kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon) and all their troops gathered together and advanced. They deployed their troops and fought against Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Gibeon sent this message to Joshua at the camp in Gilgal, “Do not abandon your subjects! Come up here quickly and rescue us! Help us! For all the Amorite kings living in the hill country are attacking us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua and his whole army, including the bravest warriors, marched up from Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Joshua, “Don’t be afraid of them, for I am handing them over to you. Not one of them can resist you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua attacked them by surprise after marching all night from Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord routed them before Israel. Israel thoroughly defeated them at Gibeon. They chased them up the road to the pass of Beth Horon and struck them down all the way to Azekah and Makkedah.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they fled from Israel on the slope leading down from Beth Horon, the Lord threw down on them large hailstones from the sky, all the way to Azekah. They died—in fact, more died from the hailstones than the Israelites killed with the sword.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: The sun stood still and the moon stood motionless while the nation took vengeance on its enemies. The event is recorded in the Scroll of the Upright One. The sun stood motionless in the middle of the sky and did not set for about a full day.
speaker: Narrator

text: There has not been a day like it before or since. The Lord listened to a human being, for the Lord fought for Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua and all Israel returned to the camp at Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The five Amorite kings ran away and hid in the cave at Makkedah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua was told, “The five kings have been found hiding in the cave at Makkedah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said, “Roll large stones over the mouth of the cave and post guards in front of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But don’t you delay! Chase your enemies and catch them. Don’t allow them to retreat to their cities, for the Lord your God is handing them over to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua and the Israelites almost totally wiped them out, but some survivors did escape to the fortified cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the whole army safely returned to Joshua at the camp in Makkedah. No one dared threaten the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said, “Open the cave’s mouth and bring the five kings out of the cave to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They did as ordered; they brought the five kings out of the cave to him—the kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they brought the kings out to Joshua, he summoned all the men of Israel and said to the commanders of the troops who accompanied him, “Come here and put your feet on the necks of these kings.” So they came up and put their feet on their necks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua said to them, “Don’t be afraid and don’t panic! Be strong and brave, for the Lord will do the same thing to all your enemies you fight.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua executed them and hung them on five trees. They were left hanging on the trees until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: At sunset Joshua ordered his men to take them down from the trees. They threw them into the cave where they had hidden and piled large stones over the mouth of the cave. (They remain to this very day.)
speaker: Narrator

text: That day Joshua captured Makkedah and put the sword to it and its king. He annihilated everyone who lived in it; he left no survivors. He did to its king what he had done to the king of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua and all Israel marched from Makkedah to Libnah and fought against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord handed it and its king over to Israel, and Israel put the sword to all who lived there; they left no survivors. They did to its king what they had done to the king of Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua and all Israel marched from Libnah to Lachish. He deployed his troops and fought against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord handed Lachish over to Israel, and they captured it on the second day. They put the sword to all who lived there, just as they had done to Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Horam of Gezer came up to help Lachish, but Joshua struck him down, as well as his army, until no survivors remained.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua and all Israel marched from Lachish to Eglon. They deployed troops and fought against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day they captured it and put the sword to all who lived there. That day they annihilated it just as they had done to Lachish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua and all Israel marched up from Eglon to Hebron and fought against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They captured it and put the sword to its king, all its surrounding cities, and all who lived in it; they left no survivors. As they had done at Eglon, they annihilated it and all who lived there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua and all Israel turned to Debir and fought against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They captured it, its king, and all its surrounding cities and put the sword to them. They annihilated everyone who lived there; they left no survivors. They did to Debir and its king what they had done to Libnah and its king and to Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua defeated the whole land, including the hill country, the Negev, the foothills, the slopes, and all their kings. He left no survivors. He annihilated everything that breathed, just as the Lord God of Israel had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua conquered the area between Kadesh Barnea and Gaza and the whole region of Goshen, all the way to Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua captured in one campaign all these kings and their lands, for the Lord God of Israel fought for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua and all Israel returned to the camp at Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Jabin of Hazor heard the news about Israel’s victories, he organized a coalition, including King Jobab of Madon, the king of Shimron, the king of Acshaph,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the northern kings who ruled in the hill country, in the rift valley south of Kinnereth, in the foothills, and on the heights of Dor to the west.
speaker: Narrator

text: Canaanites came from the east and west; Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, and Jebusites from the hill country; and Hivites from below Hermon in the area of Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These kings came out with their armies; they were as numerous as the sand on the seashore and had a large number of horses and chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these kings gathered and joined forces at the Waters of Merom to fight Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Joshua, “Don’t be afraid of them, for about this time tomorrow I will cause all of them to lie dead before Israel. You must hamstring their horses and burn their chariots.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua and his whole army caught them by surprise at the Waters of Merom and attacked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord handed them over to Israel, and they struck them down and chased them all the way to Greater Sidon, Misrephoth Maim, and the Mizpah Valley to the east. They struck them down until no survivors remained.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua did to them as the Lord had commanded him; he hamstrung their horses and burned their chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Joshua turned, captured Hazor, and struck down its king with the sword, for Hazor was at that time the leader of all these kingdoms.
speaker: Narrator

text: They annihilated everyone who lived there with the sword—no one who breathed remained—and burned Hazor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua captured all these royal cities and all their kings and annihilated them with the sword, as Moses the Lord’s servant had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Israel did not burn any of the cities located on mounds except for Hazor; it was the only one Joshua burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites plundered all the goods of these cities and the cattle, but they totally destroyed all the people and allowed no one who breathed to live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses the Lord’s servant passed on the Lord’s commands to Joshua, and Joshua did as he was told. He did not ignore any of the commands the Lord had given Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua conquered the whole land, including the hill country, all the Negev, all the land of Goshen, the foothills, the rift valley, the hill country of Israel and its foothills,
speaker: Narrator

text: from Mount Halak up to Seir, as far as Baal Gad in the Lebanon Valley below Mount Hermon. He captured all their kings and executed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua campaigned against these kings for quite some time.
speaker: Narrator

text: No city made peace with the Israelites (except the Hivites living in Gibeon); they had to conquer all of them,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Lord determined to make them obstinate so they would attack Israel. He wanted Israel to annihilate them without mercy, as he had instructed Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Joshua attacked and eliminated the Anakites from the hill country—from Hebron, Debir, Anab, and all the hill country of Judah and Israel. Joshua annihilated them and their cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: No Anakites were left in Israelite territory, though some remained in Gaza, Gath, and Ashdod.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua conquered the whole land, just as the Lord had promised Moses, and he assigned Israel their tribal portions. Then the land was free of war.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these are the kings of the land whom the Israelites defeated and drove from their land on the east side of the Jordan, from the Arnon Valley to Mount Hermon, including all the eastern rift valley:
speaker: Narrator

text: King Sihon of the Amorites who lived in Heshbon and ruled from Aroer (on the edge of the Arnon Valley)—including the city in the middle of the valley and half of Gilead—all the way to the Jabbok Valley bordering Ammonite territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: His kingdom included the eastern rift valley from the Sea of Kinnereth to the sea of the rift valley (the Salt Sea), including the route to Beth Jeshimoth and the area southward below the slopes of Pisgah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The territory of King Og of Bashan, one of the few remaining Rephaites, who lived in Ashtaroth and Edrei
speaker: Narrator

text: and ruled over Mount Hermon, Salecah, all Bashan to the border of the Geshurites and Maacathites, and half of Gilead as far as the border of King Sihon of Heshbon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses the Lord’s servant and the Israelites defeated them and Moses the Lord’s servant assigned their land to Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the kings of the land whom Joshua and the Israelites defeated on the west side of the Jordan, from Baal Gad in the Lebanon Valley to Mount Halak up to Seir. Joshua assigned this territory to the Israelite tribes,
speaker: Narrator

text: including the hill country, the foothills, the rift valley, the slopes, the wilderness, and the Negev—the land of the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites:
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Jericho (one),
the king of Ai—located near Bethel—(one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Jerusalem (one),
the king of Hebron (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Jarmuth (one),
the king of Lachish (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Eglon (one),
the king of Gezer (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Debir (one),
the king of Geder (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Hormah (one),
the king of Arad (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Libnah (one),
the king of Adullam (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Makkedah (one),
the king of Bethel (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Tappuah (one),
the king of Hepher (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Aphek (one),
the king of Lasharon (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Madon (one),
the king of Hazor (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Shimron Meron (one),
the king of Acshaph (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Taanach (one),
the king of Megiddo (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Kedesh (one),
the king of Jokneam near Carmel (one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Dor—near Naphath Dor—(one),
the king of Goyim—near Gilgal—(one),
speaker: Narrator

text:
the king of Tirzah (one), 
a total of thirty-one kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joshua was very old, the Lord told him, “You are very old, and a great deal of land remains to be conquered.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the land that remains: all the territory of the Philistines and all the Geshurites,
speaker: Narrator

text: from the Shihor River east of Egypt northward to the territory of Ekron (it is regarded as Canaanite territory), including the area belonging to the five Philistine lords who ruled in Gaza, Ashdod, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron, as well as Avvite land
speaker: Narrator

text: to the south; all the Canaanite territory, from Arah in the region of Sidon to Aphek, as far as Amorite territory;
speaker: Narrator

text: the territory of Byblos and all Lebanon to the east, from Baal Gad below Mount Hermon to Lebo Hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will drive out before the Israelites all who live in the hill country from Lebanon to Misrephoth Maim, all the Sidonians; you be sure to parcel it out to Israel as I instructed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, divide up this land among the nine tribes and the half-tribe of Manasseh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The other half of Manasseh, Reuben, and Gad received their allotted tribal lands on east side of the Jordan, just as Moses, the Lord’s servant, had assigned them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their territory started from Aroer (on the edge of the Arnon Valley), included the city in the middle of the valley, the whole plain of Medeba as far as Dibon,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all the cities of King Sihon of the Amorites who ruled in Heshbon, and ended at the Ammonite border.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their territory also included Gilead, Geshurite and Maacathite territory, all Mount Hermon, and all Bashan to Salecah—
speaker: Narrator

text: the whole kingdom of Og in Bashan, who ruled in Ashtaroth and Edrei. (He was one of the few remaining Rephaites.) Moses defeated them and took their lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites did not conquer the Geshurites and Maacathites; Geshur and Maacah live among Israel to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Moses did not assign land as an inheritance to the Levites; their inheritance is the sacrificial offerings made to the Lord God of Israel, as he instructed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses assigned land to the tribe of Reuben by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their territory started at Aroer (on the edge of the Arnon Valley) and included the city in the middle of the valley, the whole plain of Medeba,
speaker: Narrator

text: Heshbon and all its surrounding cities on the plain, including Dibon, Bamoth Baal, Beth Baal Meon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jahaz, Kedemoth, Mephaath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kiriathaim, Sibmah, Zereth Shahar on the hill in the valley,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth Peor, the slopes of Pisgah, and Beth Jeshimoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: It encompassed all the cities of the plain and the whole realm of King Sihon of the Amorites who ruled in Heshbon. Moses defeated him and the Midianite leaders Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba (they were subjects of Sihon and lived in his territory).
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites killed Balaam son of Beor, the omen reader, along with the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: The border of the tribe of Reuben was the Jordan. The land allotted to the tribe of Reuben by its clans included these cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses assigned land to the tribe of Gad by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their territory included Jazer, all the cities of Gilead, and half the Ammonite territory as far as Aroer near Rabbah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their territory ran from Heshbon to Ramath Mizpah and Betonim, and from Mahanaim to the territory of Debir.
speaker: Narrator

text: It included the valley of Beth Haram, Beth Nimrah, Sukkoth, and Zaphon, and the rest of the realm of King Sihon of Heshbon, the area east of the Jordan to the end of the Sea of Kinnereth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land allotted to the tribe of Gad by its clans included these cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses assigned land to the half-tribe of Manasseh by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their territory started at Mahanaim and encompassed all Bashan, the whole realm of King Og of Bashan, including all sixty cities in Havvoth Jair in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Half of Gilead, Ashtaroth, and Edrei, cities in the kingdom of Og in Bashan, were assigned to the descendants of Makir son of Manasseh, to half the descendants of Makir by their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the land assignments made by Moses in the rift valley plains of Moab east of the Jordan River opposite Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Moses did not assign land as an inheritance to the Levites; their inheritance is the Lord God of Israel, as he instructed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following is a record of the territory assigned to the Israelites in the land of Canaan by Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the Israelite tribal leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land assignments to the nine-and-a-half tribes were made by drawing lots, as the Lord had instructed Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Moses had assigned land to the two-and-a-half tribes east of the Jordan, but he assigned no land to the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Joseph were considered as two tribes, Manasseh and Ephraim. The Levites were allotted no territory, though they were assigned cities in which to live, along with the grazing areas for their cattle and possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites followed the Lord’s instructions to Moses and divided up the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Judah approached Joshua in Gilgal, and Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite said to him, “You know what the Lord said about you and me to Moses, the man of God, at Kadesh Barnea.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was forty years old when Moses, the Lord’s servant, sent me from Kadesh Barnea to spy on the land and I brought back to him an honest report.
speaker: Narrator

text: My countrymen who accompanied me frightened the people, but I remained loyal to the Lord my God.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day Moses made this solemn promise: ‘Surely the land on which you walked will belong to you and your descendants permanently, for you remained loyal to the Lord your God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, look, the Lord has preserved my life, just as he promised, these past forty-five years since the Lord spoke these words to Moses, while Israel traveled through the wilderness. See here, I am today eighty-five years old!
speaker: Narrator

text: Today I am still as strong as when Moses sent me out. I can fight and go about my daily activities with the same energy I had then.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, assign me this hill country that the Lord promised me at that time! No doubt you heard then that the Anakites live there in large, fortified cities. But assuming the Lord is with me, I will conquer them, as the Lord promised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua asked God to empower Caleb son of Jephunneh and assigned him Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hebron remains the assigned land of Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite to this very day because he remained loyal to the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Hebron used to be called Kiriath Arba. Arba was a famous Anakite.) Then the land was free of war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land allotted to the tribe of Judah by its clans reached to the border of Edom, to the wilderness of Zin in the Negev far to the south.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their southern border started at the southern tip of the Salt Sea,
speaker: Narrator

text: extended south of the Scorpion Ascent, crossed to Zin, went up from the south to Kadesh Barnea, crossed to Hezron, went up to Addar, and turned toward Karka.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then crossed to Azmon, extended to the Stream of Egypt, and ended at the Mediterranean Sea. This was their southern border.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eastern border was the Salt Sea to the mouth of the Jordan River.
The northern border started north of the Salt Sea at the mouth of the Jordan,
speaker: Narrator

text: went up to Beth Hoglah, crossed north of Beth Arabah, and went up to the Stone of Bohan son of Reuben.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then went up to Debir from the Valley of Achor, turning northward to Gilgal (which is opposite the Pass of Adummim south of the valley), crossed to the waters of En Shemesh and extended to En Rogel.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then went up the Valley of Ben Hinnom to the slope of the Jebusites on the south (that is, Jerusalem), going up to the top of the hill opposite the Valley of Ben Hinnom to the west, which is at the end of the Valley of the Rephaites to the north.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then went from the top of the hill to the spring of the waters of Nephtoah, extended to the cities of Mount Ephron, and went to Baalah (that is, Kiriath Jearim).
speaker: Narrator

text: It then turned from Baalah westward to Mount Seir, crossed to the slope of Mount Jearim on the north (that is Kesalon), descended to Beth Shemesh, and crossed to Timnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then extended to the slope of Ekron to the north, went toward Shikkeron, crossed to Mount Baalah, extended to Jabneel, and ended at the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The western border was the Mediterranean Sea. These were the borders of the tribe of Judah and its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Caleb son of Jephunneh was assigned Kiriath Arba (that is Hebron) within the tribe of Judah, according to the Lord’s instructions to Joshua. (Arba was the father of Anak.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Caleb drove out from there three Anakites—Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai, descendants of Anak.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there he attacked the people of Debir. (Debir used to be called Kiriath Sepher.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Caleb said, “To the man who attacks and captures Kiriath Sepher I will give my daughter Achsah as a wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb’s brother, captured it, Caleb gave Achsah his daughter to him as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: One time Achsah came and charmed her father so that she could ask him for some land. When she got down from her donkey, Caleb said to her, “What would you like?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She answered, “Please give me a special present. Since you have given me land in the Negev, now give me springs of water.” So he gave her both the upper and lower springs.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the land assigned to the tribe of Judah by its clans:
speaker: Narrator

text: These cities were located at the southern extremity of Judah’s tribal land near the border of Edom: Kabzeel, Eder, Jagur,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kinah, Dimonah, Adadah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kedesh, Hazor, Ithnan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ziph, Telem, Bealoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazor Hadattah, Kerioth Hezron (that is, Hazor),
speaker: Narrator

text: Amam, Shema, Moladah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazar Gaddah, Heshbon, Beth Pelet,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazar Shual, Beer Sheba, Biziothiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Baalah, Iim, Ezem,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eltolad, Kesil, Hormah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ziklag, Madmannah, Sansannah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Lebaoth, Shilhim, Ain, and Rimmon—a total of twenty-nine cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: These cities were in the foothills: Eshtaol, Zorah, Ashnah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zanoah, En Gannim, Tappuah, Enam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jarmuth, Adullam, Socoh, Azekah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaaraim, Adithaim, and Gederah (or Gederothaim)—a total of fourteen cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zenan, Hadashah, Migdal Gad,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dilean, Mizpah, Joktheel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Lachish, Bozkath, Eglon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Cabbon, Lahmas, Kitlish,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gederoth, Beth Dagon, Naamah, and Makkedah—a total of sixteen cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Libnah, Ether, Ashan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Iphtah, Ashnah, Nezib,
speaker: Narrator

text: Keilah, Achzib, and Mareshah—a total of nine cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ekron and its surrounding towns and settlements;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Ekron westward, all those in the vicinity of Ashdod and their towns;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ashdod with its surrounding towns and settlements, and Gaza with its surrounding towns and settlements, as far as the Stream of Egypt and the border at the Mediterranean Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: These cities were in the hill country: Shamir, Jattir, Socoh,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dannah, Kiriath Sannah (that is, Debir),
speaker: Narrator

text: Anab, Eshtemoh, Anim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Goshen, Holon, and Giloh—a total of eleven cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arab, Dumah, Eshan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Janim, Beth Tappuah, Aphekah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Humtah, Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron), and Zior—a total of nine cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Maon, Carmel, Ziph, Juttah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jezreel, Jokdeam, Zanoah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kain, Gibeah, and Timnah—a total of ten cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Halhul, Beth Zur, Gedor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Maarath, Beth Anoth, and Eltekon—a total of six cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kiriath Baal (that is, Kiriath Jearim) and Rabbah—a total of two cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: These cities were in the wilderness: Beth Arabah, Middin, Secacah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nibshan, the City of Salt, and En Gedi—a total of six cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Judah were unable to conquer the Jebusites living in Jerusalem. The Jebusites live with the people of Judah in Jerusalem to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land allotted to Joseph’s descendants extended from the Jordan at Jericho to the waters of Jericho to the east, through the desert and on up from Jericho into the hill country of Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The southern border extended from Bethel to Luz, and crossed to Arkite territory at Ataroth.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then descended westward to Japhletite territory, as far as the territory of lower Beth Horon and Gezer, and ended at the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph’s descendants, Manasseh and Ephraim, were assigned their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The territory of the tribe of Ephraim by its clans included the following: The border of their assigned land to the east was Ataroth Addar as far as upper Beth Horon.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then extended on to the sea, with Micmethath on the north. It turned eastward to Taanath Shiloh and crossed it on the east to Janoah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then descended from Janoah to Ataroth and Naarah, touched Jericho, and extended to the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Tappuah it went westward to the Valley of Kanah and ended at the sea. This is the land assigned to the tribe of Ephraim by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also included were the cities set apart for the tribe of Ephraim within Manasseh’s territory, along with their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ephraimites did not conquer the Canaanites living in Gezer. The Canaanites live among the Ephraimites to this very day and do hard labor as their servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tribe of Manasseh, Joseph’s firstborn son, was also allotted land. The descendants of Makir, Manasseh’s firstborn and the father of Gilead, received land, for they were warriors. They were assigned Gilead and Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Manasseh’s descendants were also assigned land by their clans, including the descendants of Abiezer, Helek, Asriel, Shechem, Hepher, and Shemida. These are the male descendants of Manasseh son of Joseph by their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Zelophehad son of Hepher, son of Gilead, son of Makir, son of Manasseh, had no sons, only daughters. These are the names of his daughters: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went before Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the leaders and said, “The Lord told Moses to assign us land among our relatives.” So Joshua assigned them land among their uncles, as the Lord had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh was allotted ten shares of land, in addition to the land of Gilead and Bashan east of the Jordan,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the daughters of Manasseh were assigned land among his sons. The land of Gilead belonged to the rest of the descendants of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The border of Manasseh went from Asher to Micmethath, which is near Shechem. It then went south toward those who live by En Tappuah.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The land of Tappuah belonged to Manasseh, but Tappuah, located on the border of Manasseh, belonged to the tribe of Ephraim.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The border then descended southward to the Valley of Kanah. Ephraim was assigned cities there among the cities of Manasseh, but the border of Manasseh was north of the valley and ended at the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephraim’s territory was to the south, and Manasseh’s to the north. The sea was Manasseh’s western border and their territory touched Asher on the north and Issachar on the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within Issachar’s and Asher’s territories Manasseh was assigned Beth Shean, Ibleam, the residents of Dor, the residents of Endor, the residents of Taanach, the residents of Megiddo, the three of Napheth, and the towns surrounding all these cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men of Manasseh were unable to conquer these cities; the Canaanites managed to remain in those areas.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the Israelites were strong militarily, they forced the Canaanites to do hard labor, but they never totally conquered them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Joseph said to Joshua, “Why have you assigned us only one tribal allotment? After all, we have many people, for until now the Lord has enabled us to increase in number.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua replied to them, “Since you have so many people, go up into the forest and clear out a place to live in the land of the Perizzites and Rephaites, if the hill country of Ephraim is too small for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Joseph said, “The whole hill country is inadequate for us, and the Canaanites living down in the valley in Beth Shean and its surrounding towns and in the Valley of Jezreel have chariots with iron-rimmed wheels.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said to the family of Joseph—to both Ephraim and Manasseh: “You have many people and great military strength. You will not have just one tribal allotment.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole hill country will be yours; though it is a forest, you can clear it, and it will be entirely yours. You can conquer the Canaanites, though they have chariots with iron-rimmed wheels and are strong.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire Israelite community assembled at Shiloh and there they set up the tent of meeting. Though they had subdued the land,
speaker: Narrator

text: seven Israelite tribes had not been assigned their allotted land.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua said to the Israelites: “How long do you intend to put off occupying the land the Lord God of your ancestors has given you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Pick three men from each tribe. I will send them out to walk through the land and make a map of it for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Divide it into seven regions. Judah will stay in its territory in the south, and the family of Joseph in its territory in the north.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for you, map out the land into seven regions and bring it to me. I will draw lots for you here before the Lord our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Levites will not have an allotted portion among you, for their inheritance is to serve the Lord. Gad, Reuben, and the half-tribe of Manasseh have already received their allotted land east of the Jordan, which Moses the Lord’s servant assigned them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men started out, Joshua told those going to map out the land, “Go, walk through the land, map it out, and return to me. Then I will draw lots for you before the Lord here in Shiloh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men journeyed through the land and mapped it and its cities out into seven regions on a scroll. Then they came to Joshua at the camp in Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua drew lots for them in Shiloh before the Lord and divided the land among the Israelites according to their allotted portions.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first lot belonged to the tribe of Benjamin by its clans. Their allotted territory was between Judah and Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their northern border started at the Jordan, went up to the slope of Jericho on the north, ascended westward to the hill country, and extended to the wilderness of Beth Aven.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then crossed from there to Luz, to the slope of Luz to the south (that is, Bethel), and descended to Ataroth Addar located on the hill that is south of lower Beth Horon.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then turned on the west side southward from the hill near Beth Horon on the south and extended to Kiriath Baal (that is, Kiriath Jearim), a city belonging to the tribe of Judah. This is the western border.
speaker: Narrator

text: The southern side started on the edge of Kiriath Jearim and extended westward to the spring of the waters of Nephtoah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The border then descended to the edge of the hill country near the Valley of Ben Hinnom located in the Valley of the Rephaites to the north. It descended through the Valley of Hinnom to the slope of the Jebusites to the south and then down to En Rogel.
speaker: Narrator

text: It went northward, extending to En Shemesh and Geliloth opposite the Pass of Adummim, and descended to the Stone of Bohan son of Reuben.
speaker: Narrator

text: It crossed to the slope in front of the rift valley to the north and descended into the rift valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then crossed to the slope of Beth Hoglah to the north and ended at the northern tip of the Salt Sea at the mouth of the Jordan River. This was the southern border.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Jordan River bordered it on the east. These were the borders of the land assigned to the tribe of Benjamin by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: These cities belonged to the tribe of Benjamin by its clans: Jericho, Beth Hoglah, Emek Keziz,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth Arabah, Zemaraim, Bethel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Avvim, Parah, Ophrah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kephar Ammoni, Ophni, and Geba—a total of twelve cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gibeon, Ramah, Beeroth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mizpah, Kephirah, Mozah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rekem, Irpeel, Taralah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zelah, Haeleph, the Jebusite city (that is, Jerusalem), Gibeah, and Kiriath—a total of fourteen cities and their towns. This was the land assigned to the tribe of Benjamin by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The second lot belonged to the tribe of Simeon by its clans. Their assigned land was in the middle of Judah’s assigned land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their assigned land included Beer Sheba, Moladah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hazar Shual, Balah, Ezem,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eltolad, Bethul, Hormah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ziklag, Beth Marcaboth, Hazar Susah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth Lebaoth, and Sharuhen—a total of thirteen cities and their towns,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ain, Rimmon, Ether, and Ashan—a total of four cities and their towns,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as all the towns around these cities as far as Baalath Beer (Ramah of the Negev). This was the land assigned to the tribe of Simeon by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Simeon’s assigned land was taken from Judah’s allotted portion, for Judah’s territory was too large for them; so Simeon was assigned land within Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third lot belonged to the tribe of Zebulun by its clans. The border of their territory extended to Sarid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their border went up westward to Maralah and touched Dabbesheth and the valley near Jokneam.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Sarid it turned eastward to the territory of Kisloth Tabor, extended to Daberath, and went up to Japhia.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there it crossed eastward to Gath Hepher and Eth Kazin and extended to Rimmon, turning toward Neah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then turned on the north to Hannathon and ended at the Valley of Iphtah El.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their territory included Kattah, Nahalal, Shimron, Idalah, and Bethlehem; in all they had twelve cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the land assigned to the tribe of Zebulun by its clans, including these cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fourth lot belonged to the tribe of Issachar by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their assigned land included Jezreel, Kesulloth, Shunem,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hapharaim, Shion, Anaharath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rabbith, Kishion, Ebez,
speaker: Narrator

text: Remeth, En Gannim, En Haddah and Beth Pazzez.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their border touched Tabor, Shahazumah, and Beth Shemesh, and ended at the Jordan. They had sixteen cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the land assigned to the tribe of Issachar by its clans, including these cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifth lot belonged to the tribe of Asher by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their territory included Helkath, Hali, Beten, Acshaph,
speaker: Narrator

text: Alammelech, Amad, and Mishal. Their border touched Carmel to the west and Shihor Libnath.
speaker: Narrator

text: It turned eastward toward Beth Dagon, touched Zebulun and the Valley of Iphtah El to the north, as well as Beth Emek and Neiel, and extended to Cabul on the north
speaker: Narrator

text: and on to Ebron, Rehob, Hammon, and Kanah, as far as Greater Sidon.
speaker: Narrator

text: It then turned toward Ramah as far as the fortified city of Tyre, turned to Hosah, and ended at the sea near Hebel, Achzib,
speaker: Narrator

text: Umah, Aphek, and Rehob. In all they had twenty-two cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the land assigned to the tribe of Asher by its clans, including these cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sixth lot belonged to the tribe of Naphtali by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their border started at Heleph and the oak of Zaanannim, went to Adami Nekeb, Jabneel and on to Lakkum, and ended at the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: It turned westward to Aznoth Tabor, extended from there to Hukok, touched Zebulun on the south, Asher on the west, and the Jordan on the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fortified cities included Ziddim, Zer, Hammath, Rakkath, Kinnereth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Adamah, Ramah, Hazor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kedesh, Edrei, En Hazor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Yiron, Migdal El, Horem, Beth Anath, and Beth Shemesh. In all they had nineteen cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the land assigned to the tribe of Naphtali by its clans, including these cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventh lot belonged to the tribe of Dan by its clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their assigned land included Zorah, Eshtaol, Ir Shemesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaalabbin, Aijalon, Ithlah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elon, Timnah, Ekron,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eltekeh, Gibbethon, Baalath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehud, Bene Berak, Gath Rimmon,
speaker: Narrator

text: the waters of Jarkon, and Rakkon, including the territory in front of Joppa.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The Danites failed to conquer their territory, so they went up and fought with Leshem and captured it. They put the sword to it, took possession of it, and lived in it. They renamed it Dan after their ancestor.)
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the land assigned to the tribe of Dan by its clans, including these cities and their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they finished dividing the land into its regions, the Israelites gave Joshua son of Nun some land.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Lord had instructed, they gave him the city he requested—Timnath Serah in the Ephraimite hill country. He built up the city and lived in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the land assignments that Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the Israelite tribal leaders made by drawing lots in Shiloh before the Lord at the entrance of the tent of meeting. So they finished dividing up the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord instructed Joshua:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Have the Israelites select the cities of refuge that I told you about through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who accidentally kills someone can escape there; these cities will be a place of asylum from the avenger of blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who committed manslaughter should escape to one of these cities, stand at the entrance of the city gate, and present his case to the leaders of that city. They should then bring him into the city, give him a place to stay, and let him live there.
speaker: Narrator
